articles.title: Programming Basics and Best Practices
articles.contents:
EDS 411A


Home


EDS 411A Weekly materials
 
▾


Week 1: Hello, (Capstone) world!
Week 2: Solution design skeletons
Week 3: Data Management Planning
Week 4: Testing
Week 5: Coding Perspectives
Week 6: DIP & faculty review work
Week 7: Pactice presentations
Week 10: Looking back & forward


Resources



☰


  Programming Basics and Best Practices
  

  


Some thoughts
Learning to program/data science is hard and we may not always
explain in a way that is accessible to you - So if you don’t understand
something ASK ,
Programming gets better with practice and play - try the code,
try variations on the ideas presented, make up stuff to try,
Programming means making mistakes, expect it, stay calm and try
again - if you get frustrated step away and come back; be
creative
Support each other - assign tasks but check each others
work


Best Practices for Software Development
Wilson G, Aruliah DA, Brown CT, Chue Hong NP, Davis M, et
al. (2014) Best Practices for Scientific Computing. PLoS Biol 12(1):
e1001745. doi:10.1371/journal.pbio.1001745
Blanton, B and Lenhardt, C 2014. A Scientist’s Perspective on
Sustainable Scientific Software. Journal of Open Research Software
2(1):e17, DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.5334/jors.ba
Alternative
View


Summary of Best Practices
Wilson
et al, Summary Box


Common Coding/Software Engineering Issues
Unreadable code (hard to understand, easy to forget how it works,
hard to find errors, hard to expand)
Overly complex, disorganized code (hard to find errors; hard to
modify-expand)
Insufficient testing (both during development and after)
Not tracking code changes (multiple versions, which is
correct?)


Automated Tools for Best Practices in Software Engineering
Automated tools (really useful for more complex code development (
note that capstones’s often create programs > 100 lines of code)
Automated documentation- a program that helps you to generate
documentation
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_documentation_generators
http://roxygen.org/roxygen2-manual.pdf
Automated test case development
http://r-pkgs.had.co.nz/tests.html
Automated code evolution tracking (Version Control) This you already
know https://github.com/









  This website was made with distill by RStudio.

articles.title: EDS 411A: MEDS Capstone
articles.contents:
Image: Foggy forest



Syllabus
EDS 411A Syllabus
Course description
The goal of EDS 411A is to facilitate student learning, work and progress on their MEDS Capstone project through lessons, activities, supervised and unsupervised project work, and peer review and feedback. Additionally, EDS 411A provides opportunities for professional and career development (e.g. presentation skills, writing and editing, client relations and project management).
Throughout the course, students will build on skills they have learned in prior and current MEDS courses to implement them in a real-world data science project, including:
Practice project management and reproducible workflows using tools and strategies learned in MEDS courses, establishing clear expectations for group roles and participation, and with frequent updates within and across groups
Prepare professional presentations and documentation for a data science project through presentations for client and faculty review and through the Design and Implementation Plan, and Technical Documentation
Continue to build real-world skills for data science projects through continued collaborative work in git, data analyses and statistics, data visualization and communication, and more
Implement professional skills for data science careers including code and documentation peer review, team and client relations, scheduling and organizing tools & strategies, and conflict resolution & communication
Note: Weeks 7 & 8 are practice presentations (for Faculty Reviews) and directed work on projects. Week 9 is Faculty Reviews. That’s why there aren’t shared materials for those weeks.
MEDS Capstone Project Guidelines

articles.title: Week 1: Hello, (Capstone) world!
articles.contents:
Week 1 Materials
Week 1 Slides
Week 1 Goals:
EDS 411A course and capstone introduction
Practice and dialogue about holding effective meetings in different contexts
Work on paragraph for Bren Website
Decide on a project alias
Define team roles
Schedule
1:00 - 1:30 EDS 411AB Course Intro
1:30 - 2:30 Effective Meetings
2:30 - 2:45 BREAK
2:45 - 4:00 Project pieces: alias, paragraph for website, roles
What you should do before next week:
All members should read through the MEDS Capstone Project Guidelines
By 5pm on Tuesday 17th
Hold your first client meeting and self reflect on how it went
Create your group alias, add to EDS 2023 Capstone Assignments
Finalize your summary paragraph for the Bren website, add to Capstone Summaries for MEDS Website
Make sure your project roles are updated i EDS 2023 Capstone Assignments
Bring a dataset (from your project) to next Wednesday class in a software of your choice
Emily is case@bren.ucsb.edu

articles.title: Week 10: Course wrap-up & what to expect in Spring
articles.contents:
Today’s timeline:
1:00 - 1:20: Faculty Review recap, questions, what to turn in this week
1:20 - 2:00: Best Practices for what’s coming…
2:00 - 2:15: Peer & Self Evaluations, EDS 411A Evaluation
Work on DIP
Week 10 Materials
Week 10 Slides
Best Practices
Have a great Spring Break!!!

articles.title: Week 2: Working with clients, and starting solution design
articles.contents:
Week 2 Materials
Week 2 Slides
Week 2 Goals:
Peer Review - 1 paragraph description -
Solution Design - initial schematic
Data Exploration - a first attempt
Communicating with clients and beyond
Today’s timeline:
1:00 - 1:15 - Questions & “What worked?”
1:15 - 1:30 - Peer Review of Paragraph
1:30 - 2:30 - Solution Design
2:30-2:45 - Break
2:45 - 3:20 - Data Exploration
3:20 - 3:40 - Data Exploration Show and Tell (3 minutes)
3:40 - 3:50 - Communicating with clients
3:50 - 4:00 - For next week
What you should do before next week:
Add your skeleton draft sketch of your Solution Design to Class Working Drive Week 3 Sketches before next class (you can just add a screenshot if needed, )
Note: Schematics are encouraged in your D&I plan, so this could / should end up being a final figure in your submitted document.
Turn your sketch into a Gantt chart (Casey’s class will provide some guidance here). Add a link to Class Working Drive Week 3 Gantt Chart Link Doc
Prepare a Flash Talk on your project, be ready to present in next week’s class. Add presentation to Class Working Drive Week 3 Flash Talks

articles.title: Week 3: Data Management
articles.contents:
Week 3 Materials
Week 3 Goals:
Learn about strategies for data management
Continue to work on solution design
Answer any questions on funds for your project and how to use them
Today’s timeline:
1:00-3:00 Renata Curty - Data Management Plans
3:00-3:30. Flash Talks
3:30-4:00 Bridget Mastopietro - Finanace Team Presentation
What you should do before next week:
Prepara your data management plan and be ready share. Add it (as a Google doc) to this folder on our class drive Week4/Data Management Plan
Continue to work on your solution design
Be prepared to present solution design in class (you can update materials that you submitted last week if you want to incorporate updates/changes)
Class Working Drive Week 3 Sketches
Start your project repository -and add the link here

articles.title: Week 4: Faculty reviews, responding to questions, postmortems, and flash talks
articles.contents:
Week 4 Materials
Week 4 Slides
Week 4 Goals:
Check in on Capstone Design and Implementation plan
Formalize Problem Statement
Making Progress on Solution Design
Feedback on Data Management plan
Starting to think about testing
Today’s timeline:
1:00 - 1:20 - Review of Capstone Design and Implementation Plan
1:20 - 1:50 - Problem Statement (overview, work time)
1:50 - 2:45 - Design Solution Presentations and Feedback
2:45 - 3:00 - Break
3:00 - 3:15 - Pair and Share on Data Management Plan
3:15 - 4:00 - Testing
What you should do before next week:
Draft Design and Implementation Plan (send to your advisory AND put a copy in Week 5 DIP directory)
Read this short post on different types of software testing, and this one on data quality, to understand some different testing and data quality flavors (we’ll discuss more next week)
Brainstorm different ways you are concerned your product and/or data could break / fail. Prepare a 2-slide flash talk (3 minutes, 1 presenters) to share expected breaks. This will motivate group discussions & feedback on product testing.. Put in Week 5Break/Fail directory

articles.title: Week 5: Coding, Testing..
articles.contents:
Week 5 Materials
Week 5 Slides
Week 5 Goals:
Gaining perspective on what makes good data science
Practice in code testing
Preparing for failure
Faculty Review Logistics
Solution design sharing
Today’s timeline:
1:00 - 1:45 - Announcements and Perspectives on Coding Design
1:45 - 2:30 - Code Design and Testing
2:30 - 2:45 - Test Sharing
2:45 - 3:00 - Break
3:00 - 3:10 - Failure and how to handle it
3:10 - 3:30 - Faculty Review Logistics
3:30 - 4:00 - Solution Design Peer Review
What you should do before next week:
Draft Testing Plan section of Design & Implementation Plan
Prepare a 5 minute presentation
Cover slide
Background and motivation/significance (1-2 slides
Problem Statement (1 slide)
Objective (1 slide)
Solution Design (2-3 slides)

Resources for testing
Jeff Perkel (2022) How to fix your scientific coding errors. Nature Technology Feature.
DataONE Best Practices - Data Assurance
Google Testing and Debugging in ML
Fay et al. Engineering Production-Grade Shiny Apps Ch. 11 - Build yourself a safety net
Taschuk and Wilson (2017) Ten simple rules for making research software more robust. PLOS Comp Bio.

articles.title: Week 6: DIP & faculty review work
articles.contents:
Week 6 Materials
Week 6 Slides
Week 6 Goals:
Thinking about what makes a good presentation
Incorporating feedback and make progress on problem statement, objectives and solution design
For next week
next week we are going to focus on the ‘storyline’ of your project (and presentation)
we will also start brainstorming about mock-up prototypes (or other was to give audience a sense of where you are going)
put a draft presentation in Week 7
our focus is on story (less on what the slide looks like)
you can just put text to describe a figure if you haven’t made it yet

articles.title: Week 7: Pactice presentations
articles.contents:
Week 7 Materials
Week 7 Slides
Week 7 Goals:
Practing presentation - does the storyline work?
Brainstorming on preliminary results/prototype - 1 GRAPH + 1 SKETCH
For next week
Presentation practice!
Q/A practice
put an update presentation in Week 8

articles.title: Week 7: Responding to questions, practice presentations
articles.contents:
Week 7 Materials
Week 7 Slides
Week 7 Goals:
Tips for responding to questions
Identify question bins and start brainstorming
Practice presentations and feedback for Faculty Reviews
Discuss strategies for delegating tasks (efficient coworking)
Today’s timeline:
1:00 - 1:15 - Intro, questions, reminders
1:15 - 1:45 - Efficient coworking discussion
1:45 - 2:15 - Mini-lecture - Question bins
2:15 - 2:30 - Break
2:30 - 3:00 - Identify your question bins, brainstorm 2 - 3 questions per bin
3:00 - 5:00 - Practice presentations and feedback
What you should do before next week for 411A:
Edit your Design & Implementation Plan once feedback received
Iterate on your presentation (and practice giving it)
Continue adding to your question bins
